summary: “When there’s a wall before your eyes... you smile.”
title: “When there’s a wall before your eyes... you smile.”
body:
This is a post about one of my favorite aspects of Bakugou’s redemption arc in BnHA. The reason I’m making a post about is it because I think it’s something that’s occasionally overlooked and/or misunderstood. You see, Bakugou, as we all know, is going through the process of Getting His Shit Together. He’s made some mistakes and strayed a bit from his path, and now he is working to get back on track.

But there seems to be some difference of opinion regarding which things he specifically needs to be redeemed for. I mean, some of it we all agree on. Being a dick to Deku: check. That was bad. That part is pretty unequivocal. Being a dick in general: also bad. You don’t have to be a perfect angel to everyone, but you should at least respect people on a basic level! Ignoring the whole “saving people” part of being a hero: that’s bad too. Not a crime or anything, but somewhat eyebrow-raising, and definitely something that needs to be addressed, particularly if his goal is to be The Greatest Hero Of All Time. Yeah. And last but not least, having too much pride to acknowledge his own weaknesses and accept help and wisdom from others. That was a really big one because it’s really the fundamental issue that caused all the rest of it and halted his own growth. So yeah. Needed to work on that.

“Very good,” you say, because I just finished watching Good Omens and so in this pretend conversation that we’re having, I’m imagining that you’re British, “what a tidy little summary of Bakugou Katsuki’s Assorted Sins. But I still don’t understand what the purpose of this post is.” And okay, so here’s the thing: there is one last item that is sometimes included on this list, and that is: “he’s too obsessed with winning and being strong.”

So why this post? Well, it’s because I don’t believe this last part is actually a bad thing. I feel very strongly about it in fact, and I want to talk about why that is.

(SPOILER NOTICE: There is one spoiler in here for chapter 133 of the manga. The scene in question is just a character talking about what happened in Kamino though, so if you’re caught up with the anime, this won’t actually spoil any of the future plot. Use your own discretion, basically, but I wanted to put a warning just in case.)


Okay, so every now and again I come across the opinion that Katsuki’s obsession with winning is petty and misguided. That he needs to be corrected. That Deku is the one who has it right – the important thing is saving everyone. Deku’s aspiration is more selfless and noble, whereas wanting to be strong is superficial and childish. Even Katsuki himself starts doubting whether he was right to look up to All Might’s strength.



But here’s the thing: he wasn’t wrong. Deku is the first to say it, and All Might later backs him up. There’s nothing wrong with wanting to win. Not only is there nothing wrong with it, but it’s one of the most important aspects of being a great hero. All Might himself, undoubtedly the greatest authority on the subject, confirms this: that the will to win no matter what is not just important, but necessary in order to be great. And he’s absolutely right. But to quote LeVar Burton, you don’t have to take my word for it. Let’s look at a couple of examples.



“Hang on,” you say Britishly, “isn’t this actually one of the examples that proves Izuku’s philosophy is the most important one? The whole reason Bakugou was saved is because Izuku was determined to rescue him no matter what.”

Well, yes and no. It’s true, Deku had the will to rescue that the so-called pro heroes lacked. What’s also true is that he nearly got himself killed acting on it. What saved Katsuki was All Might’s will to rescue, inspired by Deku, and combined with his own ability to actually defeat the sludge monster. This is a great example of how simply wanting to save someone isn’t enough just on its own. If you’re not strong enough to actually follow through, then in the end it makes no difference. (Which is why this encounter ends with All Might deciding to give Izuku One for All: because he sees that the potential is there, and that the only thing he’s lacking is strength. And so he gives him that.)

Now let’s look at perhaps the best example of all:



This battle is perhaps the best canon illustration of just why the will to win is so important. To be clear, wanting to save people is important too. It’s crucial (and also self-explanatory, which is why I won’t spend a whole lot of time getting into it). That’s why heroes exist in the first place – to defend people who can’t defend themselves. But here we see an entire team of heroes who are just as determined to save everyone as All Might is, and yet none of them is actually strong enough to stand up to All for One. The most they can do is clear the civilians out of the way so that All Might can fight unimpeded.

Without All Might’s strength, the heroes would have lost. A lot of people would have died. The people of Kamino were saved because All Might was able to defeat AFO. He was the only one strong enough to stand against this great evil. Everyone’s hopes were riding on him. And he didn’t back down. He found a way to win, even though it nearly cost him everything.

This is what Katsuki admires. The thing is, Katsuki’s desire to win is perceived as being just a lust for power, a shallow desire to stand at the very top. But it’s not. This is the true meaning of “win no matter what.” It’s Cap standing up, shifting into a boxing stance, and saying he can do this all day. It’s Peter Parker buried under a fuckton of rubble, screaming “come on, Spider-Man!” and summoning the strength to lift it off. It’s Miles Morales painfully getting back to his feet in order to defeat Kingpin. Mulan trying again and again to climb that post until she finally succeeds. Inigo Montoya telling the six-fingered man to prepare to die. Link standing against Ganon and silently drawing the Master Sword.

It’s about finding a way to beat the odds. It’s about not backing down even when things look bad. “I will not submit.” Because here’s the thing: “strongest” doesn’t just mean physical strength. And if you think that’s the only kind of strength that Katsuki cares about, then I would advise you to take another look at the victories that he admires the most.



It’s simple enough to find the common denominator here. In both cases, the victory is achieved despite overwhelming odds. Surrounded by enemies and outnumbered. Weakened and frail and facing off against the strongest villain there is. And winning, still, in spite of that. These are victories that All Might pulls off because he doesn’t back down and he doesn’t give up.

This is what Katsuki emulates. Look at his actions in the sports festival. He doesn’t want victory unless it means something. He doesn’t want easy wins. He wants something hard-earned, won with blood, sweat and tears (well, maybe not tears). If it’s easy, if you don’t have to work for it, then there’s no point.

And I would argue there is a kind of nobility in this type of victory, something that’s just as profoundly heroic as saving others. It’s about not giving up. It’s about determination. The kind of determination that burns within one’s core. I will not give up. I will not lose. I will win, no matter what.



It’s about saying no to fear. It’s about pushing past the obstacle in front of you. Only on the most superficial level is it just about beating people up. Everyone seems to think this – Tomura’s attempt to recruit him is predicated on this assumption – but it’s not true. His dream is to stand at the top. It’s to beat every single challenge, climb every wall, put his own determination to the test, and see if it’s enough.

He wants to be strong. Not just powerful; strong. That means inner strength just as much, if not more, than external, physical strength. The one is what spurs on the other. All Might isn’t the strongest because he’s the most powerful; he’s the strongest because he never gives up. He always finds a way to win. He always finds a way.

And again, this isn’t to say that rescuing people isn’t vitally important, of course. But the thing Katsuki never fully understood was that fighting for others makes you even stronger. It only intensifies your determination. That’s the piece he’s been missing – that, and the fact that weakness doesn’t make you weak. And he’s starting to get that now, too. Teamwork, kids. It’s good stuff.

But at the same time, it’s crucial to understand that Deku was not wrong for wanting to emulate Bakugou. U.A. wasn’t wrong to admit someone who didn’t earn a single rescue point in his exam. It was worth it, because what Katsuki does have is just as important as what he lacks. What he lacks can be taught. It is being taught. But what he has is almost impossible to duplicate if you don’t already have it, and very few people do. It’s that fire, that determination. He won’t be daunted. He doesn’t accept setbacks. He looks for solutions. He works hard. He fights with everything he has. He puts 100% into everything. He’s someone that can fall down nine times and jump up ten.



He’s not wrong. He’s not mistaken or misguided. There’s a reason All Might has been watching him almost as closely as Deku, and it’s not just because the two of them are connected. It’s because Katsuki, for all his flaws, is still a good kid brimming with heroic potential in his own right. Everything he’s experienced since coming to U.A. has helped, for sure. But the core of him has been there all along. Brave. Determined. Fierce. There’s a light there that shines just as brightly as it does in Deku. Something incorruptible.

Horikoshi Kouhei, when asked to describe his idea of what a hero is, answered that to him, “a hero is somebody who brings reassurance.” Katsuki’s own vision of a hero is someone who always gets back up. Someone who always defeats evil. This is the kind of hero he wants to be. And All Might is absolutely right – there is future greatness there.

So anyway, that’s my big rant about Bakugou and heroism. I said at the beginning of this post that this is one of my favorite things about Bakugou’s redemption arc, and it is. Namely, it’s the fact that he actually had this part of it right the whole time. That everyone goes through the first part of the series thinking, “when is someone finally going to hit this kid with a reality check?” and waiting for him to realize that Deku was correct all along, only to have All Might explain that the two of them are both right. It’s a sort of vindication. Katsuki didn’t have it all backwards; it’s just that he was missing a piece, just as Deku was missing a piece, and if they work together they can both finally complete the whole metaphorical puzzle. That is the absolute best kind of rivalry; when the two complement each other and can help each other grow. And it works because of who Bakugou is, because he too has the makings of a great hero in him.

Tl;dr Bakugou is strong as fuck because he’s determined as fuck, and he deserves some credit for it and I can’t wait to see him grow up and kick some ass. Also everyone should watch Good Omens. But yeah, the determination to win is cool and important and a good thing and yeah.

It’s about finding a way to beat the odds. It’s about not backing down even when things look bad. “I will not submit.” Because here’s the thing: “strongest” doesn’t just mean physical strength. And if you think that’s the only kind of strength that Katsuki cares about, then I would advise you to take another look at the victories that he admires the most.



It’s simple enough to find the common denominator here. In both cases, the victory is achieved despite overwhelming odds. Surrounded by enemies and outnumbered. Weakened and frail and facing off against the strongest villain there is. And winning, still, in spite of that. These are victories that All Might pulls off because he doesn’t back down and he doesn’t give up.

This is what Katsuki emulates. Look at his actions in the sports festival. He doesn’t want victory unless it means something. He doesn’t want easy wins. He wants something hard-earned, won with blood, sweat and tears (well, maybe not tears). If it’s easy, if you don’t have to work for it, then there’s no point.

And I would argue there is a kind of nobility in this type of victory, something that’s just as profoundly heroic as saving others. It’s about not giving up. It’s about determination. The kind of determination that burns within one’s core. I will not give up. I will not lose. I will win, no matter what.



It’s about saying no to fear. It’s about pushing past the obstacle in front of you. Only on the most superficial level is it just about beating people up. Everyone seems to think this – Tomura’s attempt to recruit him is predicated on this assumption – but it’s not true. His dream is to stand at the top. It’s to beat every single challenge, climb every wall, put his own determination to the test, and see if it’s enough.

He wants to be strong. Not just powerful; strong. That means inner strength just as much, if not more, than external, physical strength. The one is what spurs on the other. All Might isn’t the strongest because he’s the most powerful; he’s the strongest because he never gives up. He always finds a way to win. He always finds a way.

And again, this isn’t to say that rescuing people isn’t vitally important, of course. But the thing Katsuki never fully understood was that fighting for others makes you even stronger. It only intensifies your determination. That’s the piece he’s been missing – that, and the fact that weakness doesn’t make you weak. And he’s starting to get that now, too. Teamwork, kids. It’s good stuff.

But at the same time, it’s crucial to understand that Deku was not wrong for wanting to emulate Bakugou. U.A. wasn’t wrong to admit someone who didn’t earn a single rescue point in his exam. It was worth it, because what Katsuki does have is just as important as what he lacks. What he lacks can be taught. It is being taught. But what he has is almost impossible to duplicate if you don’t already have it, and very few people do. It’s that fire, that determination. He won’t be daunted. He doesn’t accept setbacks. He looks for solutions. He works hard. He fights with everything he has. He puts 100% into everything. He’s someone that can fall down nine times and jump up ten.



He’s not wrong. He’s not mistaken or misguided. There’s a reason All Might has been watching him almost as closely as Deku, and it’s not just because the two of them are connected. It’s because Katsuki, for all his flaws, is still a good kid brimming with heroic potential in his own right. Everything he’s experienced since coming to U.A. has helped, for sure. But the core of him has been there all along. Brave. Determined. Fierce. There’s a light there that shines just as brightly as it does in Deku. Something incorruptible.

Horikoshi Kouhei, when asked to describe his idea of what a hero is, answered that to him, “a hero is somebody who brings reassurance.” Katsuki’s own vision of a hero is someone who always gets back up. Someone who always defeats evil. This is the kind of hero he wants to be. And All Might is absolutely right – there is future greatness there.

So anyway, that’s my big rant about Bakugou and heroism. I said at the beginning of this post that this is one of my favorite things about Bakugou’s redemption arc, and it is. Namely, it’s the fact that he actually had this part of it right the whole time. That everyone goes through the first part of the series thinking, “when is someone finally going to hit this kid with a reality check?” and waiting for him to realize that Deku was correct all along, only to have All Might explain that the two of them are both right. It’s a sort of vindication. Katsuki didn’t have it all backwards; it’s just that he was missing a piece, just as Deku was missing a piece, and if they work together they can both finally complete the whole metaphorical puzzle. That is the absolute best kind of rivalry; when the two complement each other and can help each other grow. And it works because of who Bakugou is, because he too has the makings of a great hero in him.

Tl;dr Bakugou is strong as fuck because he’s determined as fuck, and he deserves some credit for it and I can’t wait to see him grow up and kick some ass. Also everyone should watch Good Omens. But yeah, the determination to win is cool and important and a good thing and yeah.
trail.content:
This is a post about one of my favorite aspects of Bakugou’s redemption arc in BnHA. The reason I’m making a post about is it because I think it’s something that’s occasionally overlooked and/or misunderstood. You see, Bakugou, as we all know, is going through the process of Getting His Shit Together. He’s made some mistakes and strayed a bit from his path, and now he is working to get back on track.

But there seems to be some difference of opinion regarding which things he specifically needs to be redeemed for. I mean, some of it we all agree on. Being a dick to Deku: check. That was bad. That part is pretty unequivocal. Being a dick in general: also bad. You don’t have to be a perfect angel to everyone, but you should at least respect people on a basic level! Ignoring the whole “saving people” part of being a hero: that’s bad too. Not a crime or anything, but somewhat eyebrow-raising, and definitely something that needs to be addressed, particularly if his goal is to be The Greatest Hero Of All Time. Yeah. And last but not least, having too much pride to acknowledge his own weaknesses and accept help and wisdom from others. That was a really big one because it’s really the fundamental issue that caused all the rest of it and halted his own growth. So yeah. Needed to work on that.

“Very good,” you say, because I just finished watching Good Omens and so in this pretend conversation that we’re having, I’m imagining that you’re British, “what a tidy little summary of Bakugou Katsuki’s Assorted Sins. But I still don’t understand what the purpose of this post is.” And okay, so here’s the thing: there is one last item that is sometimes included on this list, and that is: “he’s too obsessed with winning and being strong.”

So why this post? Well, it’s because I don’t believe this last part is actually a bad thing. I feel very strongly about it in fact, and I want to talk about why that is.

(SPOILER NOTICE: There is one spoiler in here for chapter 133 of the manga. The scene in question is just a character talking about what happened in Kamino though, so if you’re caught up with the anime, this won’t actually spoil any of the future plot. Use your own discretion, basically, but I wanted to put a warning just in case.)


Okay, so every now and again I come across the opinion that Katsuki’s obsession with winning is petty and misguided. That he needs to be corrected. That Deku is the one who has it right – the important thing is saving everyone. Deku’s aspiration is more selfless and noble, whereas wanting to be strong is superficial and childish. Even Katsuki himself starts doubting whether he was right to look up to All Might’s strength.



But here’s the thing: he wasn’t wrong. Deku is the first to say it, and All Might later backs him up. There’s nothing wrong with wanting to win. Not only is there nothing wrong with it, but it’s one of the most important aspects of being a great hero. All Might himself, undoubtedly the greatest authority on the subject, confirms this: that the will to win no matter what is not just important, but necessary in order to be great. And he’s absolutely right. But to quote LeVar Burton, you don’t have to take my word for it. Let’s look at a couple of examples.

Well, yes and no. It’s true, Deku had the will to rescue that the so-called pro heroes lacked. What’s also true is that he nearly got himself killed acting on it. What saved Katsuki was All Might’s will to rescue, inspired by Deku, and combined with his own ability to actually defeat the sludge monster. This is a great example of how simply wanting to save someone isn’t enough just on its own. If you’re not strong enough to actually follow through, then in the end it makes no difference. (Which is why this encounter ends with All Might deciding to give Izuku One for All: because he sees that the potential is there, and that the only thing he’s lacking is strength. And so he gives him that.)

Now let’s look at perhaps the best example of all:



This battle is perhaps the best canon illustration of just why the will to win is so important. To be clear, wanting to save people is important too. It’s crucial (and also self-explanatory, which is why I won’t spend a whole lot of time getting into it). That’s why heroes exist in the first place – to defend people who can’t defend themselves. But here we see an entire team of heroes who are just as determined to save everyone as All Might is, and yet none of them is actually strong enough to stand up to All for One. The most they can do is clear the civilians out of the way so that All Might can fight unimpeded.

Without All Might’s strength, the heroes would have lost. A lot of people would have died. The people of Kamino were saved because All Might was able to defeat AFO. He was the only one strong enough to stand against this great evil. Everyone’s hopes were riding on him. And he didn’t back down. He found a way to win, even though it nearly cost him everything.

title: The Disappearance of Class 1-A
description:
by deadXD

The topic of the traitor has been on everybody’s mind. And series of threats towards Class 1-A is not making the situation any better.

Students are beginning to disappear and everyone is blaming one another. What will happen to Class 1-A?

(P.S ships are in this to help with the plot and story; not meant to offend)
-

-
“̸͈̟̏̀̐́̑͝I̴̢͇̘̟̠̙̥̗͖͉̍̆̿͆'̴̛̼̺̟̥̗͉̇̈́̐̎̉̍̋̊̽̚m̴̘̹̣͒̓͌͝͝ ̶̨͎̻̖̙̙̦̦̘̝̓̎̉̐̓̓͌̀̿͝g̷̡̧̨̛̭̜̫̜͍̳͚͈̪̈l̶͖̮̳̯̞͙̖̼̼̩̪̞̔͑̍̑̃̄͝͝ą̸̢̧͔̜͚̬̥̘͂̐̂͑̍̇̋̂͜͝͝ḑ̸̬͍̳̖͖͕̪̯̂ ̴̡̖͔̭͔͎̥̭̻̼̜͒̍̏̈́̑̐w̶̡͍̰̭͠h̴̘̻̻̞̬͇̙͔̦̾̈̓̔o̴̰͒̇͌ ̵͕̌͐͗̓̓̄̓̐͘͝g̴̲̩͉̪̤͓͗ú̵̧̺̜̱̌̌̚͝y̴̡̧̛̝͖̯̼̥͓̘̥̹̾̈́͛̓̽̈́̈́s̸̡̡͓͕̥̎̽̿͋͛̏̾̈͜ ̸̫̲́̐̋̽c̷̻͔̓̾̈́͝͠͝ǫ̴͈͈͖̳͆̓̃̓͋ͅų̷̧̪̜̘̲̥̙̳͉̞̦͊̇̅̃̊̽̈͠͠l̴̨̧͕̠̗̟̯̱̥̎̎͌̊̍̈́d̷̬̤̱̈́̓͆͑̋͒̿̓̈́͘͠͠ͅ ̷̼̙̒̓̚j̴̖̜͙͇̦̤͉̟́̇̊õ̴̲̫͊̆̇͊̉i̸͎͍̮͗̈́̊̑̀͒̽̄̉̆͝ͅṇ̸͓͗̎͑̎̈ ̶̣̲͖͔͚̥̖̺͙̠̟͖͒͛͌̿̓̔͗̒t̸͚̖͖̞͓̤͎͐͜͝ḩ̶̱̤̩̌̒̃̈́̋̿̊e̴̛̗͕̳̞͋̓̓̀͂̋͐̇̊͜ ̶̛̟͈͎̹̺̮̩̀̀͘͜s̷̱͓̳̣̱̬̫͙̈̂̉́̐͂̀̃h̸̬̱̯͖̭͉͇̳̩̍̎̉͗̏̓̿̉̚͜ͅȯ̷̡̟̬̘̝̣͙͐́̈́̂͐̅̂͘͝w̸̠̠̻̺̻̪̿!̵̘͉̳̗̖̥̮̝̮͈̅̅̑̊̿͗͜͠͝"̷̳̯̹̼͔̞͈͎̣̪͓̽̽̿̐̍́̒͊͘̚͠ ̶̩͈̞̊̏͐̚͜͝ͅM̶̧̛̳̫̥̬̲͕̫͊͌͂̔͌̊̃̄̎ͅỉ̶̙̟̗͈̤͍̬̲̿̌̈̿͊̈́̾̇͘d̶̨̛͉͉̝̻̈́͆̆͆̇̎̒͠ȏ̵̢̢̡͙̝̪̑̆̐͂̈́̏́̋̈͝r̸͙̯̈́i̷̩̺̹̞̅̿̈͐́͝-̷̡͓̆͗̇̍̿̿ ̵̖̱͈̋̾̊ņ̵̛͚̞͙̟͚͓̖̏̊̆̉̆̈̓͜͝͝o̴̦̺̪̘̓̄̃͂ ̵̖̖̩́͐̎̉̇n̴̜͛͆̔̍̎̈́͐̐̚͝ö̶̩̻͒̓͋̍,̶͖̮̆͒̍̇̒͌̓͑ ̷̛̍̑̑̀͘͝͝

summary: That's All You Ever Have to Say
title: That's All You Ever Have to Say
description:
by arxaris

Maybe a sane person wouldn’t put up with it. They’d probably call the whole thing unhealthy, say that Bakugou should learn to express his feelings. People have suggested to Kirishima in the past that he put his foot down and demand they talk about things. They’ve gritted their teeth as they told him Bakugou was playing games with him, looked at him with pity as if they were cluing him into something everyone knew but him, something truly awful. But of course Kirishima knew. How could he not? Katsuki wasn’t just playing games with him. They were playing games together.

And Kirishima was positively addicted to them.

summary: A wild Good BoyTM appeared Loving the current arc and all the Dabi we’re getting. He’s probably my favourite character.  I also...
caption:
A wild Good BoyTM appeared

Loving the current arc and all the Dabi we’re getting. He’s probably my favourite character. 

I also seem to be that one rare person in the fandom that’s actually on the LOV’s side. They honestly seem more interesting to me than the heroes, with more character depth and interesting backstories, but maybe I’m just thinking that way bc I’m a massive sucker for angst.
